title: How to Find out How Long Your Computer Has Been On

steps.title: Open the Task Manager.
steps.content: Open the Task Manager . You can do this in a few different ways: Right-click the taskbar and choose Task Manager . Press Esc while you hold down ⇧ Shift + Ctrl . Press Del while you hold down Alt + Ctrl , then click Task Manager . Type "task manager" into the Start search bar, then click the Task Manager app at the top of the results.

steps.title: Click the Performance tab.
steps.content: Click the Performance tab. On Windows 10, it's at the top of the Task Manager window. If you're on Windows 11, the Performance tab is the second one on the left, with an icon of a line graph. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click the CPU tab.
steps.content: Click the CPU tab. You'll find this option on the left side of the Task Manager window. It should be the default tab when you enter the Performance tab. If you're using Windows 7 or earlier, skip this step.

steps.title: Find the "Up Time" heading.
steps.content: Find the "Up Time" heading. You'll see this in the bottom half of the Task Manager window. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the number by the "Up Time" heading.
steps.content: Look at the number by the "Up Time" heading. This number, which will appear in DD:HH:MM:SS format, dictates the amount of time for which your computer has been on since you last turned it off. For example, an Up Time value of "01:16:23:21" would mean your computer has been on for one day, sixteen hours, twenty-three minutes, and twenty-one seconds without shutting down.

steps.title: Click the Apple icon.
steps.content: Click the Apple icon. It's on the top-left corner of the screen. Doing so will display a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click System Settings.
steps.content: Click System Settings . On older versions of macOS, this may say System Preferences .

steps.title: Click General > About.
steps.content: Click General > About . General will be found in the left-hand sidebar. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click System Report.
steps.content: Click System Report . You'll see this on the left side of the "About This Mac" window.

steps.title: Click the Software heading.
steps.content: Click the Software heading. It's on the left side of window. Clicking this heading will open the "Software" overview in the main window here.

steps.title: Find the "Time since boot" heading.
steps.content: Find the "Time since boot" heading. This option is near the bottom of the list of information in the middle of the page. The number to the right of this heading determines how long your Mac has been on since its last shut-down. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Terminal.
steps.content: Open the Terminal. You'll usually find the Terminal in the application menu of your distribution. [5] X Research source If you are using GNOME, press ⊞ Win and type Terminal to find it.

steps.title: Type uptime -p and press Enter.
steps.content: Type uptime -p and press Enter . This will output your PCs uptime. [6] X Research source
